data.title: Why rockets are big
data.statement:
<<First iteration:>>
To put a payload of [[P]] Kg into orbit, a rocket needs [[F]] = [[P]] × [[C]] Kg of fuel. [[C]] being the cost (in Kg) of fuel for each Kg of payload.

<<Second iteration:>>
To lift the additional mass of [[F]] Kg, the rocket needs an extra [[F2]] = [[F]] × [[C]] Kg of fuel.

<<Third iteration:>>
To lift the additional mass of [[F2]] Kg, the rocket needs an extra [[F3]] = [[F2]] × [[C]] Kg of fuel.

<<etc...>>

After each iteration, the weight of the rocket is more and more precise.

Given [[P]] the mass of the payload to put into orbit, [[C]] the cost of fuel (in Kg) for each Kg to lift and [[N]] the number of iterations. Find the mass of the rocket.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

First iteration:
To put a payload of P Kg into orbit, a rocket needs F = P × C Kg of fuel. C being the cost (in Kg) of fuel for each Kg of payload.

Second iteration:
To lift the additional mass of F Kg, the rocket needs an extra F2 = F × C Kg of fuel.

Third iteration:
To lift the additional mass of F2 Kg, the rocket needs an extra F3 = F2 × C Kg of fuel.

etc...

After each iteration, the weight of the rocket is more and more precise.

Given P the mass of the payload to put into orbit, C the cost of fuel (in Kg) for each Kg to lift and N the number of iterations. Find the mass of the rocket.
Input
Line 1: An integer P for the mass of the payload to put into orbit.
Line 2: A float C for the cost of fuel (in Kg) for each Kg to lift.
Line 3: An integer N for the number of iterations.
Output
Line 1: An integer for the mass of the rocket in Kg (rounded to the nearest integer).
Constraints
500 ≤ P ≤ 50000
0.0 < C < 1.0
1 ≤ N ≤ 100
Example
Input
1000
0.5
1
Output
1500
